ESPN's Ford: Towns could be No. 1 NBA pick

Kentucky freshman Karl-Anthony Towns could be the No. 1 pick in the NBA draft, analyst says

ESPN's Ford: Towns could be No. 1 NBA pick

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 5:15 p.m. EST December 17, 2014

Kentucky's Karl-Anthony Towns dunks during the first half of an NCAA college basketball game Eastern Kentucky, Sunday, Dec. 7, 2014. (AP Photo/James Crisp)(Photo: AP)

1 CONNECT 31 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. For months now, the consensus has been that Duke freshman Jahlil Okafor will be the No. 1 pick in the 2015 NBA draft. Through nine college games, he has only validated that projection, especially after his 25 points, 20 rebounds and three blocks on Monday.

But ESPN draft analyst Chad Ford says Okafor has real competition for that top spot, and Kentucky freshman Karl-Anthony Towns might be the most serious challenger. That he's getting limited minutes almost nine fewer per game than Okafor in the Wildcats' two-platoon system apparently isn't hurting his pro stock at all.

"While I think Okafor has the lead on him right now, there are a contingent of NBA guys and scouts who believe that Towns' ceiling is higher," Ford said. "And because of that, depending on the team that lands the No. 1 pick, I still think he has a very good chance. He won't put up the numbers Okafor will this year, but I think people see the talent there and it'll be very interesting once we get to June.

"He could very well be the No. 1 pick in the draft."

Both Towns and Okafor are listed at 6-11, but they're different players. Okafor is 270 pounds, a traditional center who punishes in the paint. Towns is leaner, more skilled, with shooting range out to the 3-point line.

RELATED: Cauley-Stein's NBA stock soars as UK junior roars.

Towns is averaging 8.5 points, 6.3 rebounds, 2.6 blocks and 1.3 assists per game compared to Okafor's 18 points, nine rebounds, 1.7 blocks and 1.6 assists. But if you recalculate their statistics to a per-34-minutes number UK coach John Calipari's standard this season to demonstrate his players' efficiency despite reduced playing time it's a tighter comparison.

Those averages: 15.3 points, 11.3 rebounds, 4.8 blocks, 2.3 assists for Towns and 22.2 points, 11.1 rebounds, 2.1 blocks and 1.9 assists for Okafor.

However you slice it, though, the Cats' crowded frontcourt does not appear to have negatively affected anyone's draft standing. In fact, Kentucky's top four post players are all on the rise each of them in the top 30 of Ford's latest "Big Board" released Wednesday.

Towns is No. 3, junior center Willie Cauley-Stein No. 8, freshman forward Trey Lyles No. 22 and sophomore center Dakari Johnson No. 29.

"It's interesting. It's the bigs all the way around for Kentucky," Ford said. "I think the guards have struggled to wow anybody. I think Devin Booker has a chance of cracking the first round because of how well he shoots the ball, though he's been inconsistent doing that. Everybody loves Tyler Ulis, but his size is a detriment from the NBA perspective.

"But those bigs, I think all of them will hear their names called in the first round."

COURIER-JOURNAL

Kentucky's Karl-Anthony Towns a student of basketball history and famous frowns past

The 6-10 Lyles, playing small forward for the Cats but likely a power forward at the next level, is averaging 7.8 points, 5.6 rebounds and 1.4 assists in just 19.4 minutes per game. But he's moved into the starting lineup now that junior Alex Poythress is out for the rest of the season with a torn ACL.

"I think Trey Lyles has helped himself," Ford said, "and I think he'll help himself even more now that Poythress is out. That's going to open up more (time) and more consistency for him. He's a third Kentucky player who could end up in the lottery."

Johnson, a 7-footer who has slimmed down dramatically and is running and jumping like never before, has "cemented his place in the first round" by returning for a second season at UK. He's averaging 9.2 points, 6.0 rebounds and 1.1 blocks per game in just 18.5 minutes.

As for the injured Poythress, a former McDonald's All-American who twice thought about bolting for the NBA and twice returned to school, Ford said he should make that same decision after this season.

Says he he wanted to challenge himself with a more serious approach to the game. Kyle Tucker, The C-J

"He was a fringe second-round guy (before the injury) and I think Alex needs to go back to school," Ford said. "The raw talent is there. The skill development still hasn't happened the way we'd like, but I don't think he's going to get that skill development at the NBA level, and coming off a torn ACL there's zero chance he cracks the first round.

"If he comes back next year, given his elite athletic ability, he could be one of those rare seniors that cracks the first round. I think he definitely should return to school. He's not ready to play in the NBA. You're seeing it over and over again with these second-round guys. It's tough. If he comes out, he'll be in the D-League next year."

Kentucky's roster, then, features both ends of the spectrum for NBA hopefuls. But the draft is still six months away, and these things tend to change.

Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.

UK ON ESPN'S 2015 NBA DRAFT "BIG BOARD"

3. Karl-Anthony Towns, 6-11 C

8. Willie Cauley-Stein, 7-0 C

21. Trey Lyles, 6-10 PF

29. Dakari Johnson, 7-0 C

UK opponents on the Big Board: No. 5 Kevon Looney, 6-10 PF, UCLA; No. 7 Myles Turner, 7-0 PF, Texas; No. 14 Kelly Oubre, 6-7 SF, Kansas; No. 16 Montrezl Harrell, 6-7, PF, Louisville; No. 18 Cliff Alexander, 6-8 PF, Kansas; No. 22 Terry Rozier, 6-2 PG, Louisville; No. 26 Chris Walker, 6-10 PF, Florida; No. 28 Bobby Portis, 6-11 PF, Arkansas.

RELATED: Chad Ford's complete "Big Board" (ESPN Insider subscription required)
